body.div:
Download Holodeck 1.0.1 Holodeck 1.0.1 bundles everything to run out-of-the-box: it has tomcat-6.0.20, axis-1.5.1, apache derby, and apache ActiveMQ-5.3. You can download the binaries from here: holodeck-1.0.1_full.zip
To download the latest source code from subversion, issue the following command (this assumes you have installed an SVN client on your machine, like "TortoiseSVN" for example):
svn co https://holodeck-b2b.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/holodeck-b2b holodeck

div.p: Holodeck version 1.0 is distributed in several packages for your convenience. The first package, called "Full Holodeck" consists of the Holodeck implementation bundled with Axis2-1.4.1, Derby, Tomcat-6.0.20, and ActiveMQ 5.3.
The second package, called "Holodeck", contains Axis2, Derby, and Tomcat but does not contain ActiveMQ.

The third package, called "Light Holodeck", contains only Axis2 and Derby and does not contain Tomcat and ActiveMQ, and therefore is intended to those users who already have a tomcat instance running on their machine and do not want to download another instance of tomcat.
The first two packages ("Full Holodeck" and "Holodeck") run out-of-the-box. The third package would need to be first deployed on Tomcat (or any Servlet Container) before it can run.
The last package (holodeck-1.0_src.zip) is the source code of Holodeck
Holodeck 1.0 is distributed under the LGPL license.

tr.td:
Full Holodeck 1.0 (zip)
(holodeck + Axis2 + Derby + Tomcat + ActiveMQ)
1.6 or above (as of this moment, the latest JDK version is 1.6.0_16). This is mandatory. The user must have this installed on his/her machine. See installation instruction below...

Holodeck is a J2EE web application and needs a J2EE Servlet Container to run. Any J2EE Server would do the job (Tomcat, JBoss, WebLogic, WebSphere, etc...). We recommend the latest version of Tomcat as it is small in size. The latest version of Tomcat is included in the first two packages ("Full Holodeck" and "Holodeck") as well as in holodeck 1.0.1.

ActiveMQ (or any JMS Provider of your choice) is an optional component. Use it only if you want Holodeck to communicate with JMS. In Holodeck 1.0, only the first package ("Full Holodeck") includes ActiveMQ. If you are using the second or third package and you also want JMS support, then you can download ActiveMQ separately from http://activemq.apache.org/. If you are using Holodeck 1.0.1, you don't need to download ActiveMQ because it runs embedded in the package.

Tomcat is already included the first and second package (for holodeck 1.0), as well as holodeck 1.0.1. You would need to download Tomcat only if you are using the third package of holodeck 1.0 ("Light Holodeck").

All Holodeck packages come bundled with apache derby database which is a very fast, scalable and performant database server that can run both as embedded or as a server (by default it runs embedded inside holodeck). You have nothing to download to make this work. If however, you prefer to use another relational database server like MySQL, Oracle, etc..., then you would have to install the database server yourself, and then create the database tables from provided scripts (Do not do this unless you don't mind manually configuring things and you know how to play with databases. See instructions below on how to accomplish this...).

p.i: Holodeck is a Java product, so you must have Java installed in order to proceed. More precisely, you need a Java Development Kit (JDK) 1.6 or later, the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) is not sufficient.

ol.li: Unzip the distribution archive, i.e. holodeck-1.0-.zip to the directory where you wish to install Holodeck 1.0. These instructions assume you chose D:\Servers\Holodeck-1.0. The subdirectory holodeck-1.0 will be created from the archive.

If JDK-1.6.20 is not yet installed on your machine, then download it , Add the JAVA_HOME environment variable by opening up the system properties (WinKey + Pause), selecting the "Advanced" tab, and the "Environment Variables" button, then adding the JAVA_HOME variable in the user variables with the value D:\Java\jdk-1.6.20 (here we are assuming this is the directory where you installed JDK). If JAVA_HOME already exists in your user variables or in the system variables, then you are already set.
In the same dialog, make sure that %JAVA_HOME%\bin exists in the value of your PATH variable.

Optional: Install Tomcat as a windows service. You can do this by issuing the following command from a DOS window: service install (this command should be executed from the Holodeck-1.0\server\bin directory
That's it for the installation.

div.p: The following instructions are only for those users who want to use MySQL database server instead of the apache derby that is bundled with Holodeck. Note that there is no difference between apache derby and MySQL. They are both performant databases (derby is even faster and scalable). The only reason you would prefer MySQL over derby could be because you already have MySQL running in your department and many collegues are using it and you want them to access the database while holodeck is running.

ol.li: If you don't have MySQL Server already installed, then you can download an installer from Sun from this location MySQL installer.

Assuming that MySQL is well installed and running as a windows service, then you need to create two databases: (a) The first database is called "ebms3" and the user accessing this database is also called "ebms3" (the password is also "ebms3"). If you want to change the name of the database or the username/password, then you will have to also modify the file "Holodeck-1.0\msh\WEB-INF\classes\META-INF\persistence.xml" so that it matches the database name and username/password that you have chosen. (b) The second database you have to create is called "wsrm" (the username/password accessing this database is also "wsrm/wsrm").

Once you created the two databases "ebms3" and "wsrm", then you have to create tables for these databases. Holodeck comes with DDL files (SQL files) that contain SQL script to create the tables for you. You can find those sql scripts in the folder "Holodeck-1.0\store\derby\": these sql files are called "ebms3-schema-mysql.ddl" and "reliability-schema-mysql.ddl". Also, if you want Holodeck to use MySQL server, you also need to modify the file "Holodeck-1.0\msh\WEB-INF\modules\holodeck-ebms3\META-INF\module.xml" and modify the value of the parameter called "PersistenceUnit" from "ebms3-derby" to "ebms3-mysql". Similarly, you would have to do the same to the file "Holodeck-1.0\msh\WEB-INF\modules\holodeck-reliability\META-INF\module.xml".

div.h3: Instructions for using another Tomcat Server
div.p: These instructions are only for those users who already have tomcat installed on their machine prior to downloading holodeck, and they want to run holodeck on their pre-existing tomcat instance. In this case, you just need to deploy holodeck web application on tomcat (Holodeck web application is the folder "Holodeck-1.0\msh"). To do this, in notepad you create a new file in which you enter the following:

and save the file as "holodeck.xml" under your "tomcat/conf/Catalina/localhost" directory. Here we assumed that "Holodeck-1.0" directory is under "D:\Servers" folder. Then you edit the file "D:/Servers/Holodeck-1.0/msh/WEB-INF/classes/META-INF/persistence.xml" and change the sentence "jdbc:derby:../../store/derby/wsrmDB;create=false" to "jdbc:derby:D:/Servers/Holodeck-1.0/store/derby/wsrmDB;create=false". There are two such sentences in the file (do a search for "jdbc:derby:../../store/derby/wsrmDB;create=false").

ol.li: Configure the PModes or create new PMode files (See documentation on PModes).

Run Holodeck. To run Holodeck you only need to start the J2EE Servlet Container in which Holodeck is deployed. If you are using Tomcat which is bundled with Holodeck, then just start Tomcat by executing the batch file Holodeck-1.0/server/bin/startup.bat or by starting the tomcat windows service (if you have installed tomcat as a windows service).
